timeline.bodyText: out of curiosity - these strings that are built as a bunch of ids to be used in an 'IN' query, can those not be used as an argument in a prepared statement? because if they can't then the statement preparation won't have an effect as this will change the database's view of what the statement is and mean caching is ineffective. There are few examples but it's the same general question
timeline.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText:
For what I've understood, "?" can only be replaced by scalars. Integers, strings... but not more complex type.
However, i can't find anything on sqlite official documentation that confirm or deny it. So I expect to test it by running the code on my smartphone and seeing whether it raise an exception or not. However, I wanted feedback on the work already done before considering doing more, in order to avoid loosing time.
Note that even if I can't prepare more this statement, those changes are far from being useless. Indeed, each time you need to refill the queue, each time you call reset in the scheduler, you'll have the exact same list of active deck, so the second time the query is executed, it'll be recognized as the same query.
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

timeline.bodyText: is _deckLimit() constant here? or should it be a prepared statement '?' argument as well?
timeline.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText: It's not. It was a mistake of mine. Honestly, that's a nightmare to do correctly. I proof read before doing the PR, but it will definitively needs help to check everything is done correctly.
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

timeline.message:
Prepared queries

In order to improve speed of code, preparred queries are better than
creating queries where values change. So here they are.

It also adds a few methods in libanki/DB.java in order to allow more
preparred queries.

Queries with IN are not entirely preparred. This is because ? can only
be replaced by constant I believe. I'll test and push in another
commit. Note that preparring partly those queries is still
interesting. Indeed, sometime the query won't change the "IN ...."
part and only change some other part. This way, preparation won't be wasted

timeline.bodyText: Does requery support named parameters? If we do, we can reduce this to just sending did which would be a little more clear. Something along the lines of https://stackoverflow.com/a/27235389
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: I've not seem anything related to named parameter in the library, otherwise I'd be happy to use it.
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

replies.bodyText:
Looks like it's unsupported, that's a shame.
requery/requery#793
replies.author: david-allison-1

timeline.bodyText:
I know we follow Anki downstream here, but mId != 0 ? mId : 0 makes very little sense in a strongly typed language.
Ref: https://github.com/ankitects/anki/blob/862e2b48f06dadf414d171d2cfdc4ac3ad79e7da/pylib/anki/notes.py#L195
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: I agree it makes no sens. However, I tried to make a change which is as small as possible.  Which is hard to write with a straight face given it touchs hundreds of line. But my point here is that I prefer that, at least in this commit, the only changes are done by moving parameters, and not actually by improving them.
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

timeline.bodyText: Flagging the missing null, assume this is intentional.
timeline.author: david-allison-1
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -778,8 +785,9 @@ protected boolean _fillRev() {
                             .getDb()
                             .getDatabase()
                             .query(
-                                    "SELECT id FROM cards WHERE did = " + did + " AND queue = " + Consts.QUEUE_TYPE_REV + " AND due <= " + mToday
-                                            + " LIMIT " + lim, null);
+                                    "SELECT id FROM cards WHERE did = ? AND queue = " + Consts.QUEUE_TYPE_REV + " AND due <= ?"

replies.bodyText:
Yeah.
The null represented the fact that there was no bindings. It was there instead of the array of object. I assume the point used to be that it allows typing to work, or something like that. So anyway, it's normal that it disappears
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: Corrected by a push force normally
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

timeline.bodyText: (nit) I know we're copying from the original, but it'd be nice to space out the due<=?
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText:
I'd really prefer to limit this change to be as small as possible in this commit. However, I'd be happy to see a bunch of other commit improving readability.
If Mike tells me to add spaces, I'll do it
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

replies.bodyText: small changes are beautiful :-). Can always add commits or separate PRs later
replies.author: mikehardy

timeline.bodyText: I'll ask whether queryColumn is the correct abstraction here. We seem to only be using it to pass in 0, querySingleColumn would be more descriptive, and would reduce the surface for bugs.
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: Similar remark, you're theoretically right, but not for this commit. At least not if we want to keep it readable. It'll clearly be great in another commit
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

timeline.author: david-allison-1

timeline.message:
Prepared queries

In order to improve speed of code, preparred queries are better than
creating queries where values change. So here they are.

It also adds a few methods in libanki/DB.java in order to allow more
preparred queries.

Queries with IN are not entirely preparred. This is because ? can only
be replaced by constant I believe. I'll test and push in another
commit. Note that preparring partly those queries is still
interesting. Indeed, sometime the query won't change the "IN ...."
part and only change some other part. This way, preparation won't be wasted
